Testing private methods

I will confess to being somewhat confused by all the concern over testing
private methods. If you are coding in a 'test-first' style, then the tests will
drive your code, and any private methods you end up with must invariably be
called by one of your public methods. If you have a private method, and the
_only_ way to test it is to use reflection, or make it public, or use an inner
class, what is it doing? If its not used by any of your tested code, why is it
there at all? I know other instances of the same class can call private
methods, but I have never yet seen an application that relied upon this feature,
and if you have objects of the same class calling private methods on each other,
I would consider that an indication that the design needs work. Even if it is
necessary, surely the object making the private call must be doing so
(ultimately) in response to a public/protected/package method call? Which you
can test.

If your method chains are so large its hard to pinpoint the problem when a unit
test fails, then perhaps some refactoring is in order to break up the chain. A
method call should generally perform one discreet action. In almost every
application I've seen where hard-to-find bugs are causing problems, many of them
could be reduced by making the methods smaller, and having more of them. As
long as each method does one well-defined thing, and is sensibly named, having
more small methods will cause less confusion than having methods that are 300
lines long.

Regards,

-Darren
